cards.front:
The right coronary artery supplies blood to the:

A. left ventricle and posterior wall of the right ventricle.
B. right atrium and posterior wall of the right ventricle.
C. right ventricle and inferior wall of the left ventricle.
D. left ventricle and inferior wall of the right atrium.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: right ventricle and inferior wall of the left ventricle.

cards.front:
When preparing to obtain a 12-lead ECG, the LL and RL electrodes should be placed:

A. on the lower abdomen.
B. on either side of the chest.
C. on the thighs or ankles.
D. anywhere on the arms.
See Cardiac Monitoring

In contrast to the sympathetic nervous system, the parasympathetic nervous system:

A. causes an increase in the heart rate.
B. prepares the body to handle stress.
C. slows the heart and respiratory rates.
D. dilates the blood vessels in the muscles.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: slows the heart and respiratory rates.

cards.front:
Upon arriving at the residence of a patient with a possible cardiac problem, it is MOST important to:

A. assess the scene for potential hazards.
B. gain immediate access to the patient.
C. determine if you need additional help.
D. request a paramedic unit for assistance.
See Patient Assessment
cards.back: assess the scene for potential hazards.

cards.front:
Which of the following signs is commonly observed in patients with right-sided heart failure?

A. Labored breathing
B. Flat jugular veins
C. Dependent edema
D. Pulmonary edema
See Pathophysiology

The electrical impulse generated by the heart originates in the:

A. atrioventricular node.
B. coronary sinus.
C. sinoatrial node.
D. bundle of His.
See Anatomy and Physiology

Deoxygenated blood from the body returns to the:

A. left atrium.
B. right ventricle.
C. right atrium.
D. left ventricle.
See Anatomy and Physiology

When documenting a patient’s description of his or her chest pain or discomfort, the EMT should:

A. document his or her own perception.
B. underline the patient’s quotes.
C. use the patient’s own words.
D. use medical terminology.
See Pathophysiology

A dissecting aortic aneurysm occurs when:

A. the inner layers of the aorta become separated.
B. a weakened area develops in the aortic wall.
C. all layers of the aorta suddenly contract.
D. the aorta ruptures, resulting in profound bleeding.
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: the inner layers of the aorta become separated.

cards.front:
Cardiogenic shock following AMI is caused by:

A. decreased pumping force of the heart muscle.
B. widespread dilation of the systemic vasculature.
C. a profound increase in the patient’s heart rate.
D. hypovolemia secondary to severe vomiting.
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: decreased pumping force of the heart muscle.

cards.front:
Which of the following medications is commonly given to patients with chest pain to prevent blood clots from forming or getting bigger?

A. Metoprolol (Toprol)
B. Aspirin
C. Oxygen
D. Furosemide (Lasix)
See Emergency Medical Care for Chest Pain or Discomfort

The AED is MOST advantageous to the EMT because:

A. it delivers prompt defibrillation to patients with ventricular fibrillation.
B. it is lightweight, easy to use, and safe for the EMT who is using it.
C. its use does not require the presence of advanced life support personnel.
D. it delivers an unlimited number of shocks with the same amount of energy.
See Cardiac Arrest
cards.back: it delivers prompt defibrillation to patients with ventricular fibrillation.

cards.front:
Angina pectoris occurs when:

A. a coronary artery is totally occluded by plaque.
B. one or more coronary arteries suddenly spasm.
C. myocardial oxygen demand exceeds supply.
D. myocardial oxygen supply exceeds the demand.
See Pathophysiology

Which of the following statements regarding nitroglycerin is correct?

A. Nitroglycerin should be administered between the cheek and gum.
B. Nitroglycerin usually relieves anginal chest pain within 5 minutes.
C. The potency of nitroglycerin is increased when exposed to light.
D. A maximum of five nitroglycerin doses should be given to a patient.
See Emergency Medical Care for Chest Pain or Discomfort
cards.back: Nitroglycerin usually relieves anginal chest pain within 5 minutes.

cards.front:
The MOST common reason that many people experiencing AMI do not seek immediate medical attention is because they:

A. are elderly.
B. cannot afford it.
C. are in denial.
D. do not trust EMTs.
See Pathophysiology

Most patients are instructed by their physician to take up to _______ doses of nitroglycerin before calling EMS.

A. two
B. five
C. four
D. three
See Emergency Medical Care for Chest Pain or Discomfort

Narrowing of the coronary arteries caused by a buildup of fatty deposits is called:

A. angina pectoris.
B. arteriosclerosis.
C. acute ischemia.
D. atherosclerosis.
See Pathophysiology

Prior to attaching the AED to a cardiac arrest patient, the EMT should:

A. contact medical control.
B. assess for a pulse for 20 seconds.
C. perform CPR for 30 seconds.
D. dry the chest if it is wet.
See Cardiac Arrest
cards.back: dry the chest if it is wet.

cards.front:
The iliac arteries immediately subdivide into the:

A. femoral arteries.
B. anterior tibial arteries.
C. posterior tibial arteries.
D. peroneal arteries.
See Anatomy and Physiology

Which of the following blood vessels transports oxygenated blood?

A. Pulmonary arteries
B. Inferior vena cava
C. Superior vena cava
D. Pulmonary veins
See Anatomy and Physiology
